original_data.question: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute onset neck pain and enlargement. Specifically, he reports that he has been experiencing pain and swelling of the anterior portion of his neck near the midline. Otherwise, he says that he has been getting tired easily and feels cold often. Physical exam reveals a painful diffusely enlarged thyroid gland with many small nodules. A biopsy is obtained showing diffuse cellular hyperplasia with areas of focal colloid hyperplasia. Given these findings, the patient is started on appropriate therapy, and the neck mass becomes smaller over time. Which of the following is most likely associated with the cause of this patient's symptoms?

model_response:
This patient most likely has Graves disease, which is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. The disease is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies to the TSH receptor stimulate the thyroid to produce thyroid hormone. The antibodies are directed against the receptor for TSH, which is located on the thyroid follicular cell membrane. The antibodies stimulate the cells to grow and divide, producing more thyroid hormone. The antibodies are directed against the TSH receptor because of a genetic association with the HLA-B8 haplotype. The antibodies are not produced in response to an infectious agent, nor are they produced as a result of an embryologic remnant. The inflammatory process is not the stimulus for the antibody production.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Intensely discomforting, distressful, or agonizing sensation associated with trauma or disease, with well-defined location, character, and timing.
General increase in bulk of a part or organ due to CELL ENLARGEMENT and accumulation of FLUIDS AND SECRETIONS, not due to tumor formation, nor to an increase in the number of cells (HYPERPLASIA).
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
Of or involving the front of a main body.
One of the portions into which something is regarded as divided and which together constitute a whole.
A medial line, especially the medial line or medial plane of the body (or some part of the body).
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
Relative coldness of a body part to palpitation, often acccompanied by feelings of coldness. [PMID:16770929, PMID:32491414]
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Widely spread; not localized or confined.

A highly vascularized endocrine gland consisting of two lobes joined by a thin band of tissue with one lobe on each side of the TRACHEA. It secretes THYROID HORMONES from the follicular cells and CALCITONIN from the parafollicular cells thereby regulating METABOLISM and CALCIUM level in blood, respectively.
A small lump, swelling or collection of tissue.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
An increased number of Leydig cells in the hilar region of the ovary. (WHO 2020)
Limited to a specific area.
An increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ without tumor formation. It differs from HYPERTROPHY, which is an increase in bulk without an increase in the number of cells.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
An abnormal growth in the neck.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)
Joined in some kind of relationship.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
